  • cs122b-2019-winter-project1

    v1 v1  
     1[[PageOutline]]
     2
     3= CS122B: Project 1 =
     4'''Due: Week 3 Monday, 01/21, 11:45pm. Due on Github.'''[[BR]]
     5
     6= Tasks =
     7 1. Setup Apache Tomcat (on your development machine)
     8 1. Setup an Amazon AWS instance
     9 1. Join Github Organization and create a repo for your team
     10 1. Create a MySQL database with provided movie info
     11 1. Implement the Movie List page of the Fablix Application
     12
     13----
     14= Task 1: Setup Apache Tomcat =
     15We assume you already have Java installed on your machine. We recommend at least Java 8.
     16
     17Download and install the latest Apache Tomcat from https://tomcat.apache.org/download-80.cgi#8.5.29 on your development machine. Go to "8.5.29" -> "Binary Distributions" -> "Core", for Mac and Linux, download the "zip" file, for Windows, download the "32-bit or 64-bit Windows zip".Unzip the downloaded file.
     18
     19Follow this [https://javatutorial.net/how-to-install-and-configure-tomcat-8 Install and Configure Tomcat 8 tutorial] to set up Tomcat. For the "Change Servlet Compiler to use Java 8" section, the "conf/web.xml" doesn't have the lines as the tutorial said. You can add these lines to the place suggested by the tutorial.
     20
     21 * For Mac and Linux users, you may need to give permission to the "sh" files by going to the "bin" folder and then running: ` sudo chmod +x *.sh `
     22 * Be sure to change your Tomcat password to something else than "admin". Otherwise your website will be very vulnerable.
     23
     24You should see the following interfaces if you setup Tomcat successfully: [https://grape.ics.uci.edu/wiki/public/attachment/wiki/cs122b-2019-winter-project1/tomcat-startup-interface.png Screenshot 1], [https://grape.ics.uci.edu/wiki/public/attachment/wiki/cs122b-2019-winter-project1/tomcat-app-manager.png Screenshot 2]
     25
     26== Apache Tomcat Eclipse Integration ==
     27Apache Tomcat makes hosting your applications easy. The Eclipse IDE makes development easy.  We recommend you to use the latest version of Eclipse EE (EE stands for Enterprise Edition and has built-in support for application and web servers including Tomcat)
     28
     29Eclipse Downloads:
     30 * [https://www.eclipse.org/downloads/packages/eclipse-ide-java-ee-developers/oxygen3 Eclipse EE Edition (recommended) ]
     31 * [http://www.eclipse.org/downloads/packages/eclipse-ide-java-developers/oxygen3 Eclipse Standard Edition]
     32
     33The following tutorial is a quick start guide and will help you set up your development environment in eclipse. ''Use the latest Tomcat version instead of the shown version in the tutorial''.     ''Note'': If you opt for Eclipse EE edition, you can skip the installation of Eclipse Web Tools Platform when following the quick start guide.
     34
     35 * [http://www.mulesoft.com/tomcat-eclipse Apache Tomcat Eclipse Integration Quickstart Guide]
     36
     37These tutorials can also be helpful
     38
     39 * [http://o7planning.org/en/10209/installing-and-configuring-tomcat-server-in-eclipse Install and Configure Tomcat Server in Eclipse]
     40 * [https://javatutorial.net/run-tomcat-from-eclipse Run Tomcat from Eclipse]
     41
     42== Setup Maven ==
     43Maven is a tool to manage project dependencies and automate the build process.
     44
     45Maven is built in with Eclipse. But to run it on command line you also need to install maven on your development machine.
     46
     47To install Maven:
     48 - Windows: follow [https://www.google.com/search?q=install+maven+on+windows&oq=install+maven+on+windows&aqs=chrome..69i57j0l5.3082j0j4&sourceid=chrome&ie=UTF-8 this tutorial]
     49 - Mac: Run "brew install maven"
     50 - Ubuntu: Run "sudo apt-get install maven"
     51
     52
     53= Task 2: Setup an AWS Instance =
     54[[Span(id=setup-aws)]]You need to launch an Amazon [https://aws.amazon.com/console/ AWS EC2 instance] to repeat the tasks above. Make sure to use the '''free-tier 64-bit Ubuntu instances''' so that we can make our future instructions consistent. You are welcome to participate in the ​[https://aws.amazon.com/education/awseducate/ AWS Educate] program, which can provide $100 AWS credits per student. (UCI is a member institution.)
     55
     56Generally, similar to many other tasks in this quarter, we expect you to figure out how to do many tasks by reading online materials.  [https://aws.amazon.com/free/ This] link is a good place to start from.
     57
     58== Launch a free AWS EC2 instance ==
     59 1. Go to [https://aws.amazon.com/console/ AWS Console] to sign up. You will need to enter a valid credit card. Don't worry; as long as you choose a free-tier instance and remove it after the end of the quarter, you will not be charged.
     60 1. When you are done, login to the AWS console.
     61 1. Launch a new '''Ubuntu 16.04''' free-tier '''t2.micro''' EC2 instance. Notice that you need to generate and download a key to ssh to the machine, and it may take a few minutes for the instance to be initialized.
     62 1. After the instance is running, you will see a public IP address assigned to it. Keep this IP: you are required to give us this IP to demo project 1.
     63 1. When viewing the list of instances, you can click on the "connect" button, on the top to get instructions on how to use SSH to connect to the instance. By default, only the SSH port, 22, is open. In order to get other services (e.g., HTTP, HTTPS, and Tomcat) to be available to other machines, you will need to open the corresponding ports. '''To do so, when the instance is checked, select the security group, go to the "inbound" tab, and add more rules'''.
     64
     65== Setup MySQL and !Apache/Tomcat on the AWS instance ==
     66This part assumes you have SSH access to the Ubuntu 14.04 AWS instance.
     67
     68 1. [https://www.digitalocean.com/community/tutorials/how-to-install-mysql-on-ubuntu-16-04 Install MySQL].
     69 1. [https://help.ubuntu.com/lts/serverguide/httpd.html Install Apache Web server]. '''Open port 80'''.
     70 1. [https://medium.com/coderscorner/installing-oracle-java-8-in-ubuntu-16-10-845507b13343 Install Java] [[BR]]
     71 1. [https://grape.ics.uci.edu/wiki/public/wiki/cs122b-2018-spring-project1-install-tomcat-on-aws Install Tomcat on AWS]. Setup its application app manager page and test it using the URL http://YOUR_PUBLIC_IP:8080/manager/html. '''Open port 8080'''. This part is a little tricky, so read the instructions carefully.
     72 1. Install Maven: "sudo apt-get install maven"
     73
     74Here are two cheat sheets of !Linux/Ubuntu commands:
     75
     76 * http://cli.learncodethehardway.org/bash_cheat_sheet.pdf
     77 * http://www.cheat-sheets.org/saved-copy/ubunturef.pdf
     78
     79= Task 3: Join Github Organization and create a repo for your team. =
     80This course uses Github for version control. The students are expected to use Github as explained below.
     81
     82 * Create an account on Github if you don't have one. Then provide us your username in the Google Spreadsheet [https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1e3sr9DYy3OXAxaD5s0dYzAJ1HbjuuR7aJvyP2JT3Ix4/edit?usp=sharing Github Usernames].
     83 * Wait for the invitation from our staff to join the [https://github.com/UCI-Chenli-teaching UCI-Chenli-teaching organization]. The invitation might take a few days to be sent out based on our schedule.
     84 * One member from each team needs to create a '''private''' repository. The repository name should be of the form 'cs122b-spring18-team-x' where 'x' is your assigned team number, e.g., "cs122b-spring18-team-1". Other members can then be added to the repository as collaborators (by following steps given [https://help.github.com/articles/inviting-collaborators-to-a-personal-repository/ here]).
     85 * You must wait for the invitation from us and '''create a private repository within the organization UCI-Chenli-teaching'''. Don't create a private repository on your own. 1) Go to [https://github.com/UCI-Chenli-teaching UCI-Chenli-teaching organization]. 2) click the '''New''' button to create a repository. 3) Type in the name and choose '''private'''.
     86
     87Create repo under the organization
     88
     89[[Image(wiki:cs122b-2019-winter-project1:create-repo-button.png)]]
     90
     91Type the repo name properly and choose "private"
     92
     93[[Image(wiki:cs122b-2019-winter-project1:create-repo-interface.png)]]
     94
     95 * You can then begin with your project using Github. Put the code of your project in your team's Github repository.
     96
     97We have a [https://grape.ics.uci.edu/wiki/public/wiki/cs122b-2019-winter-project1-git wiki] to get you started with Github for this course. Go through one of these online tutorials to get familiar with Git and Github if you are not familiar with them.
     98
     99 * https://try.github.io
     100 * https://product.hubspot.com/blog/git-and-github-tutorial-for-beginners
     101
     102
     103= Task 4: Create a MySQL Database =
     104 * Download a MySQL database for your development machine from http://dev.mysql.com/downloads/mysql/;
     105 * Create a database called "moviedb" with the following tables:[[BR]]
     106
     107|| Table Name[[BR]] || Attributes[[BR]] || Notes ||
     108|| movies[[BR]] || !id:varchar(10) (primary key)[[BR]] !title:varchar(100) [[BR]] !year:integer [[BR]] !director:varchar(100) [[BR]] || required [[BR]] required [[BR]] required [[BR]] required ||
     109|| stars[[BR]] || !id:varchar(10) (primary key)[[BR]] !name:varchar(100) [[BR]] !birthYear:integer [[BR]] || required[[BR]] required [[BR]] not required[[BR]] ||
     110|| stars_in_movies[[BR]] || !starId:varchar(10), referencing stars.id[[BR]] !movieId:varchar(10), referencing movies.id[[BR]] || all attributes required ||
     111|| genres[[BR]] || !id:integer (primary key)[[BR]] !name:varchar(32) [[BR]] || all attributes required; "id" should be [[BR]]"AUTO_INCREMENT" ||
     112|| genres_in_movies[[BR]] || !genreId:integer, referencing genres.id[[BR]] !movieId:varchar(10]), referencing movies.id[[BR]] || all attributes required ||
     113|| customers[[BR]] || !id:integer (primary key)[[BR]] !firstName:varchar(50) [[BR]] !lastName:varchar(50) [[BR]] !ccId:varchar(20), referencing creditcards.id[[BR]] !address:varchar(200) [[BR]] !email:varchar(50) [[BR]] !password:varchar(20) [[BR]] || all attributes required; "id" should be [[BR]]"AUTO_INCREMENT" ||
     114|| sales[[BR]] || !id:integer (primary key)[[BR]]       !customerId:integer, referencing customers.id[[BR]] !movieId:varchar(10), referencing movies.id[[BR]] !saleDate:date  [[BR]] || all attributes required; "id" should be [[BR]]"AUTO_INCREMENT" ||
     115|| creditcards[[BR]] || !id:varchar(20), (primary key)[[BR]] !firstName:varchar(50) [[BR]] !lastName:varchar(50) [[BR]] !expiration:date [[BR]] || all attributes required ||
     116|| ratings[[BR]] || !movieId:varchar(10), referencing movies.id[[BR]] !rating:float [[BR]] !numVotes:integer [[BR]] || all attributes required ||
     117
     118The table-creation SQL statements should be written in a '''createtable.sql''' file.  All varchar() fields for which there is no data (i.e., the fields contents are missing or unknown) are the empty string (!''); other non-required fields which have no data are null. Required fields have the constraint that they are not null. [[BR]] [[BR]]
     119
     120 * Use the provided [attachment:movie-data.sql] file to populate the tables.
     121
     122
     123= Task 5: Implement the Movie List page of the Fablix Application =
     124[[Image(wiki:cs122b-2019-winter-project1:122b-project1-diagram.jpg)]]
     125
     126You only need to implement the Movie List page of the Fablix Application. You'll implement all other parts in project 2. You do NOT need to implement the sorting and prev/next features.
     127
     128In project 1, the "Movie list" page shows the top 20 rated movies, sorted by the rating. You don't need to show all the movies. Each movie needs to contain the following information:
     129
     130 * title
     131 * year;
     132 * director;
     133 * list of genres;
     134 * list of stars
     135 * rating
     136
     137
     138== Create Your project in Eclipse ==
     139
     140To create project 1 in eclipse, you need to create a dynamic web project.
     141
     142Follow [https://grape.ics.uci.edu/wiki/public/wiki/cs122b-2019-winter-project1-eclipse-project Create New Project in Eclipse] to properly setup your project 1 in Eclipse.
     143
     144Make sure that the project1 Eclipse project is created '''within your git repository folder'''.
     145
     146If you meet any problems, [http://www.thejavageek.com/2013/10/22/creating-new-dynamic-web-project-eclipse/ this guide] can also be helpful.
     147
     148
     149== Setup gitignore file ==
     150When put your project code in the Git repository, a good practice of using Git is to only put the source code files in the Git repository, and ignore all the compiled files (such as .class files, executables) and other irrelevant files (such as files generated by Eclipse). The purpose of ".gitignore" file is to tell git to ignore certain files according to some patterns. You can learn more about gitignore [https://medium.com/@haydar_ai/learning-how-to-git-ignoring-files-and-folders-using-gitignore-177556afdbe3 here].
     151
     152We provide a sample [https://grape.ics.uci.edu/wiki/public/attachment/wiki/cs122b-2019-winter-project1/gitignore gitignore] file that you can directly use in your project. Download the file and put the file into your project git folder. Then rename the file from "gitignore" to ".gitignore" (notice we '''add a dot''' "." in the beginning). For Mac and Linux users, the file then become hidden, don't worry, this is the correct behavior. Go to the terminal and type "git status" and you can see the ".gitignore" file. For Windows users, see [https://stackoverflow.com/questions/10744305/how-to-create-gitignore-file this stackoverflow question] to create the ".gitignore" file. Git will then automatically read the ".gitignore" file and ignore the unnecessary files.
     153
     154
     155= Examples and Resources =
     156
     157== JDBC ==
     158Your Java Servlet need to talk to MySQL using JDBC. Download a MySQL JDBC driver file from ​https://dev.mysql.com/downloads/connector/j
     159
     160[[Span(id=jdbc-samples)]]Here are some sample JDBC programs. The [attachment:cs122b-setup-scripts.txt Setup Scripts] will give you the instructions on how to create the required database/tables and how to execute the sample code.
     161
     162 * [attachment:cs122b-setup-scripts.txt Setup Scripts]
     163 * [attachment:JDBC1.java JDBC1.java - obtaining metadata and table contents]
     164 * [attachment:JDBC2.java JDBC2.java - deleting a record]
     165
     166== Tomcat Servlet Example ==
     167[[Span(id=TomcatExample)]]
     168
     169You are recommend to implement project 1 using the Java servlet techniques covered in the class.
     170
     171We've prepared this [https://github.com/UCI-Chenli-teaching/project1-star-example project1-star-example] that help you get started. This project contains a Java Servlet that talks to MySQL to get star information and return an HTML to display a table of stars.
     172
     173Follow [https://grape.ics.uci.edu/wiki/public/wiki/cs122b-2018-spring-project1-import-project Import Project to Eclipse] to import this example project to Eclipse and export the WAR file.
     174
     175You can run the project directly from Eclipse if you finished the Eclipse Tomcat Integration steps. To directly deploy the WAR file to tomcat, you can either deploy it through the tomcat manager webpage, or deploy it through the command line.
     176
     177To deploy the WAR file using Tomcat manager webpage:
     178 1. Start the Tomcat server. Go to http://localhost:8080; this is your local web page. The tomcat welcome page should appear.
     179 2. Click "Tomcat Manager", enter your tomcat admin username and password.
     180 3. Under "Deploy directory or WAR file located on server" you should see a deploy button. You need not specify a path. If you simply click the deploy button, Tomcat will automatically refresh its list of applications.
     181 4. the new project should appear in the list. Click on the name of the project, and it should take you to the index.html page
     182 5. To see the star servlet, go to "localhost:8080/project1-star-example/stars", you should see a table containing star information.
     183
     184To deploy the WAR file in command line:
     185 1. generate the WAR file using "mvn clean package". The war file is in the "target" folder.
     186 2. copy the WAR file to "tomcat_directory/webapps". For example "cp target/project1-star-example.war tomcat_directory/webapps/"
     187
     188
     189== Other Online Resources ==
     190Here are some relevant tutorials. You can start the project after learning the basics. Don't spend too much time on learning the advanced content. You won't use them until Project 2.
     191
     192 * HTML and CSS tutorial: http://htmldog.com/guides/html/beginner/
     193 * An interactive HTML tutorial (Seems the tutorial is broken as of 1/7/2018, it may get fixed): https://www.codecademy.com/ar/tracks/htmlcss
     194 * A good Java Servlet Tutorial: http://tutorials.jenkov.com/java-servlets/index.html
     195 * Another good Java Servlet Tutorial: http://o7planning.org/en/10169/java-servlet-tutorial
     196
     197
     198= Project Submission =
     199We'll take your Github code as submissions. You need to include all the code in your Github repository, including Java, SQL, HTML, CSS, etc... You don't have to submit anything on EEE.
     200
     201On the night of the end of the grace period, we will run a script that gets the latest commit ID in your repository. We'll use the time of the latest commit to determine if you use the Grace Period or not. So if you don't plan to use the Grace Period, don't push anything to Github during the 24-hour Grace Period. After the 24-hour grace period, you can continue using your repository normally for the next project.
     202
     203 * Remember that we will only be checking the code in the '''master branch''' of your repository.
     204 * Do not try to cheat, e.g., by modifying the timestamp of a commit to an earlier date. We'll use the time that you push your commits to Github. So be sure to push your changes to Github before the deadline!  Such cheating cases will be subject to very bad consequences.
     205 * To avoid any surprises, we will be publishing the final commit number that we have recorded for every team. It's your responsibility to check the commit number published by us. If you think we have made a mistake on the commit ID, you need to tell us ASAP.
     206
     207= Grading Checklist =
     208Please refer to the [https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1e3sr9DYy3OXAxaD5s0dYzAJ1HbjuuR7aJvyP2JT3Ix4/edit#gid=918652784 grading checklist] before submitting your project. This checklist includes the items we are looking for to grade your projects. Notice that we reserve the right to make reasonable changes of this checklist. Thus, you should implement all the required features, and only use this checklist to make sure you don't miss anything.
     209
     210= Demonstration =
     211'''You are required to demonstrate  this project'''. Your task is to show us '''(in 15 minutes)''' that your work is correctly and completely carried out and the course project is ready to move to phase 2. Your demo will include the following steps:
     212
     213a) Make sure you AWS instance has everything properly installed (Java, MySQL, Tomcat, git). Make sure that the Tomcat server is running and the Tomcat admin page is accessible.
     214
     215b) On the AWS instance, clone your project repository before the demo. During the demo, show us that you checkout to the commit ID that we recorded. You can use these commands:
     216{{{
     217git checkout master // checkout to the master branch
     218git status // show us nothing is changed in your repository
     219git log // the first commit ID that shows up should match the commit ID we have
     220
     221If "git status" shows that some files are changed, we can use "git stash" to temporarily revert the changed files. You can use "git stash pop" to get those files back later.
     222}}}
     223
     224c) On the AWS instance, you should drop the moviedb before the demo. Your repository should contain the "create_table.sql" file that you write. Use your "create_table.sql"  to show us that you can create the moviedb and all the tables. Download the movie-data.sql file using "wget https://grape.ics.uci.edu/wiki/public/raw-attachment/wiki/cs122b-2018-spring-project1/movie-data.sql", then populate the tables using the data sql file.
     225
     226d) On your local development machine, you should already have your git repository. During the demo, do "get checkout master" first, then checkout to the commit ID that we recorded.
     227
     228e) If you use Eclipse, then you should already have your project in Eclipse. Show us that the project in Eclipse is in your git repository. Export the WAR file using Eclipse (right click -> export -> WAR file). If you are not using Eclipse, you should figure out how to compile the project properly and generate the WAR file on your own.
     229
     230f) Open your AWS instance's Tomcat admin console on your browser, deploy the WAR file you just exported. Go to your webpage and demonstrate the correctness, completeness, and performance of all the required features.
     231
     232
     233We can ask questions during the demo. Each of the team members needs to show that you understand what's going on with you project. Failing to answer the questions will lead to deductions.
     234
     235Before the demo, you SHOULD test the whole process on you own. '''You will have no more than 15 minutes to demonstrate'''.  It is completely up to you to plan your demo so that all the required features are displayed and the grader  can see the quality of your work in the given time frame.''' If a group's demonstration appears to be unstructured, the demo could be aborted and rescheduled for another time''' with a substantial '''grade penalty'''.
     236
     237Demonstration schedule will be posted later.
